text:
Excellent suggestion. Also, you can list the concrete contributions you made to the work as well. This is fairly common on more senior academic CVs but for job positions (not papers) and allows you to highlight the significance of your work in relationship to the paper and outcomes related to it.

But, yeah, screw the idea that authorship is precious like this. If you removing your contributions would have made the paper objectively worse, then in my book there is no excuse not to have someone as a co-author.
